awd_titl_txt: NeTS: Medium: Collaborative Research: Riding the Stress Wave: Integrated Monitoring, Communications, and Networking for Subsea Infrastructure
awd_abstract_narration:
Thousands of miles of pipelines crisscrossing the Gulf of Mexico seafloor are the veins for the offshore oil and gas industry in the U.S. and the world. Leaks and ruptures in those pipelines lead to not only enormous economic loss but also environmental disasters. The goal of this project is to effectively monitor the subsea infrastructure such as offshore pipelines, and efficiently deliver the sensed information for subsequent control and action. To provide a viable solution, this project will integrate piezoelectric transducer designs, acoustic communications, stress wave communications (SWC), and hybrid networking, and conduct experiments and field tests to validate the proposed designs. Such a vision needs efforts from both engineering and scientific perspectives, and the success of the proposed transformative research will significantly improve the design, analysis and implementation of subsea infrastructure monitoring and data transmission systems. The research outcomes will potentially contribute to a future subsea Internet of Things and ocean big data systems, and have impact on offshore oil and gas industry, pollution control, ocean agriculture, disaster rescue, etc. The project will also provide special interdisciplinary training opportunities for both graduate and undergraduate students, particularly women and minority students, across multiple institutions through both research work and related courses.

This project aims to develop an effective subsea infrastructure health monitoring, and efficient information delivery network design via five synergistic thrusts: (1) structural health monitoring, which will employ Lead Zirconate Titanate (PZT) transducers to perform integrated structural health monitoring of pipelines, including impact, leakage, and damage detection, and explore how to send the detected damage information via SWC; (2) SWC channel modeling, which will conduct model analysis and simulation of SWC traveling along a fluid-filled pipeline in the subsea environment, and characterize SWC channels in a complicated pipeline network; (3) adaptive time reversal acoustic communications, which will characterize the acoustic communication channel in high frequency bands of 80-200 kilohertz for short range transmissions in the ocean and develop new adaptive communication receivers and strategies based on time reversal processing; (4) hybrid subsea network development, which will develop a hybrid subsea wireless network to integrate traditional acoustic communications and SWC depending on the subsea infrastructure, and study the hybrid network performance from multiple perspectives; (5) integrated experimental validation, which will conduct a series of lab and at-sea field tests on campus and at industrial/academic collaborators' sites to verify the proposed designs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Thousands of miles of pipelines deployed on the Gulf of Mexico sea floor are the veins of offshore oil and gas industries. The leaks and ruptures of those pipelines lead to enormous economic losses and environmental disasters. This proposal aims to develop novel solutions to monitor the subsea infrastructure and deliver the sensed information for resource management and disaster prevention. The project utilizes stress waves as the communication and sensing medium, combines stress wave communications with acoustic communications for underwater data transmissions, and develops integrative hybrid networks to monitor the underwater infrastructure’s structural health.

Collaborating with colleagues from the University of Houston and Texas Southern University, we focus on developing adaptive acoustic communication schemes suitable for undersea applications. The objectives are to establish high-frequency acoustic communication methods and implement adaptive communication strategies for efficient data transmissions. Based on data collected from an at-sea experiment in the Gulf of Mexico, we have performed channel characterization, adaptive receiver design, and algorithm validation for the high acoustic frequency band of 80 to 200 kHz. Multiple adaptive strategies have been developed for point-to-point mobile communications or a group of mobile nodes. These results have been published in three journal articles [1-3] and three conference papers [4-6]. We have supported the University of Houston for channel identification in pipeline stress wave communications, resulting in a joint journal publication [7].

Through the research experience for undergraduate (REU) supplements, the project also supported multiple undergraduate students who learned underwater wireless communications through the participation of field tests and measurement-based signal processing. Two of the REU students presented a poster at the 14th International Conference on Underwater Networks & Systems (WUWNet’19) in October 2019 [8]. The project supported one Ph.D. student (who graduated in May 2022) [9] and one MS student (who graduated in Aug 2022) [10].

The principal investigator (PI) and graduate students have participated in various outreach and engagement activities. Graduate and REU students from this project supported MATHCOUNTS Tuscaloosa competitions (2018 to 2022), helping with registration and organizing competitions. The investigator, undergraduate researchers, and graduate students participated in the annual E-Day exhibitions at the University of Alabama, showcasing adaptive acoustic communication research to the public. Computer projects for ECE 493/593 Digital Signal Processing were developed based on acoustic channel identification and equalization research related to this project. The PI at the University of Alabama worked together with colleagues at the University of Houston to organize WUWNet ’19. One of the highlights was the special sessions for underwater Internet of things (uw-IoT) and underwater mobile networks, which highlighted the community’s current work related to adaptive communications and IoT applications for underwater environments.

 

Publications

[1] X. Tu, X. Xu, and A. Song, “Statistical Analysis and Hybrid Modeling of High-Frequency Underwater Acoustic Channels Affected by Wind-Driven Surface Waves,” J. Acoust. Soc. Am., May. 2022. DOI: 10.1121/10.0011398.

[2] Q. Fu, A. Song, F. Zhang, and M. Pan, “Reinforcement Learning-based Trajectory Optimization for Data Muling with Underwater Mobile Nodes,” IEEE Access, Apr. 2022. DOI: 10.1109/ACCESS.2022.3165046.

[3] X. Tu, X. Xu, and A. Song, “Frequency-Domain Decision Feedback Equalization for Single-Carrier Transmissions in Fast Time-Varying Underwater Acoustic Channels,” IEEE J. Ocean. Eng., 46(2), April 2021. DOI: 10.1109/JOE.2020.3000319.

[4] Connor L. Webb, Syed Murtaza Rizvi, Aswanth Sampathkumar, Brodie Alexander, Aijun Song, Fumin Zhang, “Integration of Acoustic Communication with Underwater Autonomy: A Case Study,” WUWNet’22, Nov 11-14, Boston, MA.

[5] Q. Fu, A. Song, Q. Tao, and F. Zhang, M. Pan, “Virtual MIMO Transmissions for Underwater Acoustic Communications with Moving Platforms,” WUWNet’19, Oct 21-24, Atlanta, GA.

[6] Q Fu, A Song, “Adaptive Modulation for Underwater Acoustic Communications Based on Reinforcement Learning,” MTS/IEEE OCEANS, Charleston, 1-8, Oct 2018.

[7] D. Wei, C. Qi, C. Huang, J. Chen, A. Song, G. Song, M. Pan, “Riding Stress Wave: Underwater Communications through Pipeline Networks,” IEEE J. Ocean. Eng., 46 (4), Oct. 2021. DOI: 10.1109/JOE.2021.3085098.

[8] Andrew Sucato and Zach Wimsatt, “NSF REU Project: Development of Autonomous Surface Platforms for Acoustic Data Collection,” The 14th International Conference on Underwater Networks & Systems, Atlanta, Oct 23-25, 2019.

[9] Qiang Fu, Ph.D., University of Alabama, May 2022. Thesis: Reinforcement Learning-based mobile underwater acoustic communications.

[10] Connor Webb, M. S., University of Alabama, Aug 2022. Thesis: Integrating acoustic communications with underwater autonomy.
